citation.article-title: Recharacterization and emended description of the genus Mycoplana and description of two new species Mycoplana ramosa and Mycoplana segnis.

p.s: Emended description of Mycoplana dimorpha Gray and Thornton 1928.

Reduction of nitrate is variable. The Voges- Proskauer test is positive. Catalase positive. Acid is produced from L-arabinose, D-xylose, D-glucose, D-mannose, D-fructose, D-galactose, D-sorbitol, D-mannitol, and glycerol oxidatively, but acid is not produced from maltose, sucrose, lactose, trehalose, inositol, and soluble starch. L-Arabinose, D-xylose, D-glucose, D-mannose, D-fructose, D-galactose, maltose, sucrose, D-sorbitol, D-mannitol, glycerol, succinic acid, L-glutamic acid, L-asparatic acid, acetic acid, putrescine, spermidine, and spermine are utilized as sole sources of carbon, but lactose, trehalose, inositol, soluble starch, citric acid, formic acid, methanol, ethanol, n-butanol, monomethylamine, methane, and butane are not. Biotin is required for growth. Ammonia and urea are utilized as sole sources of nitrogen. Most strains utilize nitrate as a sole nitrogen source. The DNA base composition ranges from 64 to 65 mol% G+C. The major hydroxy fatty acid is 3-hydroxy- C14:0 acid.
The type strain is strain TK0055 (= ATCC 4279 = IFO 13291 = NCIB 9439), which was isolated from soil by Gray and Thornton in 1928.
The DNA base composition of the type strain is 64.5 mol% G+C.
Isolate TKO066 is also an M. dimorpha strain.
